{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox settlement |official_name = Município de João Pessoa |nickname = ''Sun Gate''
''Green City'' |motto = ''INTREPIDA AB ORIGINE'' |image_skyline = Montagem João Pessoa.jpg |image_caption= ''João Pessoa skyline'' |imagesize = |image_flag = Bandeira de João Pessoa.svg |image_seal = Brasão de João Pessoa.svg |image_map = Brazil Paraiba Joao Pessoa location map.svg |mapsize = 250px |map_caption = Location of João Pessoa in the state of Paraíba |pushpin_map =Brazil |pushpin_map_caption = Location of João Pessoa in Brazil |subdivision_type = Country |subdivision_type1 = [[Regions of Brazil|Region]] |subdivision_type2 = [[States of Brazil|State]] |subdivision_name = Brazil |subdivision_name1 = [[Northeast Region, Brazil|Northeast]] |subdivision_name2 = [[File:Bandeira da Paraíba.svg|border|23px]] [[Paraíba]] |leader_title = [[List of mayors of João Pessoa, Paraíba|Prefeito]] |leader_name = Luciano Cartaxo ([[Social Democratic Party (Brazil, 2011)|PSD]]) |area_note = |area_total_km2 = 211.475 |population_as_of = 2010 |population_total = 801,718 |population_density_km2 = |population_metro = |timezone = [[UTC]]−3 |utc_offset = −3 |timezone_DST = |utc_offset_DST = |coordinates = {{coord|07|05|00|S|34|50|00|W|region:BR|display=inline,title}} |elevation_m = 40 |website = [http://www.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/] |footnotes = ||settlement_type = Municipality|name = João Pessoa}} [[File:Ponta do Seixas João Pessoa.jpg|thumb|[[Ponta do Seixas]], the easternmost point of America]] [[File:Rio Jaguaribe - João Pessoa - Paraíba - Brasil.jpg|thumb|[[Jaguaribe River]]]] '''João Pessoa''' ({{IPA-pt|ʒʊˈɐ̃w peˈsoɐ|br}})The [[European Portuguese]] pronunciation is {{IPA-pt|ʒwɐ̃w pɨˈso.ɐ|}}. is the capital of the state of [[Paraíba]] in Brazil. It was founded in 1585 and it is also known as ''the city where the sun rises first'', because it is the easternmost city in the Americas at 34° 47′ 38″ W, 7° 9′ 28″ S. Its easternmost point is known as [[Ponta do Seixas]]. The city is often referred as "the second greenest in the world", with more than {{convert|7|km2|sqmi}} of forested land, second only to Paris, France,{{cite web|url=http://www.cob.org.br/olimpiadasescolares_fase2/edicao2008/cidade.asp|title=Onde o Sol brilha primeiro|publisher=Câmara Municipal de João Pessoa|accessdate=March 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090408083629/http://www.cob.org.br/olimpiadasescolares_fase2/edicao2008/cidade.asp|archivedate=April 8, 2009|df=}} though such claim seems to be just a publicity stunt from the then mayor during [[Earth Summit]].{{citar web|url=https://g1.globo.com/pb/paraiba/noticia/cidade-mais-verde-extremo-oriental-saiba-o-que-e-verdade-sobre-joao-pessoa.ghtml|title=Cidade mais verde? Extremo oriental? Saiba o que é verdade sobre João Pessoa|publisher=[[Grupo Globo|G1]]|language=pt-BR}} It is the state's largest city, with an estimated population of 801,718 of inhabitants.{{cite web|url=http://cod.ibge.gov.br/B4GJ|title=Paraíba " João Pessoa|accessdate=November 26, 2016|date=July 1, 2016|publisher=Instituto Brasileiro de Geografia e Estatística (IBGE)}} Its [[metropolitan area]] comprises eight other satellite cities (Bayeux, Cabedelo, [[Conde, Paraíba|Conde]], [[Lucena, Brazil|Lucena]], [[Santa Rita, Paraíba|Santa Rita]], and others), totalling 1,223,000 of inhabitants.{{Citation needed|date=November 2016}} The new "Estação Ciência, Cultura e Artes" (Science, Culture and Art Station),{{cite book|url=http://www.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/projetos/estacaocienciaculturaartes/|title=ESTAÇÃO CIÊNCIA, CULTURA e ARTES|publisher=E.C.C.A.|location=joão pessoa, Brazil|format=PDF|isbn=85-240-3919-1|accessdate=January 10, 2008|year=2006|language=Portuguese|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071224214719/http://www.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/projetos/estacaocienciaculturaartes/|archivedate=December 24, 2007|df=}} located at the most eastern point of the Americas (''Ponta das Seixas''), is both an educational and cultural institution as well as a national landmark. The complex, inaugurated in 2008, was created by Brazilian architect [[Oscar Niemeyer]] and is one of his last projects. The capital of Paraíba received in 2017 the title of [[creative city]] by [[UNESCO]],{{cite web|url=http://www.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/titulo-de-cidade-criativa-da-unesco-coloca-joao-pessoa-na-rota-turistica-mundial-atraves-da-arte-popular/|title=Unesco Creative City title puts João Pessoa on the world tourist route through folk art|accessdate=August 29, 2018|date=November 3, 2017|publisher=City Hall of João Pessoa}} placing João Pessoa, as "'''Brazilian city of [[handicrafts]]'''". Besides the capital of Paraíba, just another city in Latin America, it has the same title, with the same category, which is [[Chordeleg]], in [[Ecuador]]. The recognition of the capital João Pessoa, places it on the Brazilian tourist route for the richness of its [[handicrafts|popular art]]. This recognition had great contribution and influence, due to the mermaids project of Penha;{{cite web|url=https://turismo.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/o-que-fazer/pontos-turisticos/artesanato/sereias-da-penha/|title=Mermaids from Penha|accessdate=August 29, 2018|publisher=Secretary of Tourism of the Municipality of João Pessoa}} where women artisans perform the manual work, dialoguing with the design, fashion, creative economy, highlighting the art with fish scales in copper wires. ==History== João Pessoa is the third oldest city in Brazil.{{cite web|url=http://www.lonelyplanet.com/brazil/the-northeast/joao-pessoa|title=Introducing João Pessoa|publisher=Lonely Planet|accessdate=May 10, 2014}} Previously named Frederikstadt by the [[Dutch Brazil|Dutch]] and Parahyba by the [[Colonial Brazil|Portuguese]], the city was renamed for a governor of Paraíba state [[João Pessoa Cavalcanti de Albuquerque]] after his assassination in 1930. ==Geography== ===Environment=== João Pessoa has a {{convert|20|km|mi}} beachfront. João Pessoa has many green areas distributed among its avenues, parks, and residential neighborhoods, which support its claim as "the second greenest city in the world" with more than {{convert|7|km2|sqmi}} of forested land, second only to Paris. It was considered thus in 1992 after a survey of urban centres in various countries carried out by the United Nations (source: Embassy of Brazil in the UK).{{cite book|url=http://www.brazil.org.uk/page.php?n=354|title=Green City|publisher=UK Embassy|location=joão pessoa, Brazil|format=PDF|isbn=85-240-3919-1|accessdate=January 10, 2008|year=2006}}{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ===Climate=== João Pessoa has a [[tropical monsoon climate]] ([[Köppen climate classification|Köppen]] ''Am'') with very warm temperatures all year long and strong rainfall in most of the months; however, October to December have a rather low rainfall.

==Demographics== According to the IBGE of 2009, there were 801,718 people residing in the city. The racial makeup of the city was 45.72% [[White Brazilian|White]], 38.72% [[Pardo]] (two or more races), 2.77% [[Afro-Brazilian|Black]], and 0.25% [[Asian Brazilian|Asian]] or [[Indigenous peoples in Brazil|Amerindian]].{{cite book|url=http://www.sidra.ibge.gov.br/bda/tabela/listabl.asp?z=cd&o=7&i=P&c=2094|title=Síntese de Indicadores Sociais 2000|publisher=[[Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics|IBGE]]|location=João Pessoa, Brazil|format=PDF|isbn=85-240-3919-1|accessdate=January 31, 2009|year=2000|language=Portuguese}} ===Religion=== [[File:Igreja_da_Ordem_Terceira_do_Carmo_(2RC_3250).jpg|thumb|Facade of the church Our Lady of Carmen]] [[File:Mosteiro de São Bento, JPA.jpg|thumb|Monastery of St. benedict]] [[File:Altar-mor da Catedral Basílica de Nossa Senhora das Neves.jpg|thumb|main altar of the [[Cathedral Basilica of Our Lady of the Snows, João Pessoa]]]] [[File:Basílica NS das Neves - panoramio.jpg|thumb|Basilica of the Church of Our Lady of the Snows]] {| class="wikitable" |- ! Number |- style="text-align:center;" |[[Catholic]] |74.06% |442,841 |- style="text-align:center;" |[[Protestant]] |15.92% |95,191 |- style="text-align:center;" |[[Atheism|No religion]] |7.41% |44,332 |- style="text-align:center;" |[[Spiritism|Spiritist]] |1.10% |6,571 |} ''Source: [[Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics|IBGE]] 2000.[http://www.sidra.ibge.gov.br/bda/tabela/protabl.asp?c=2094&z=cd&o=7&i=P Religion in João Pessoa by IBGE] '' [[File:Presidente Castro Pinto International Airport.jpg|thumb|right|International Airport.]] == Transportation== ===International airport=== Joao Pessoa is served by [[Presidente Castro Pinto International Airport]].{{cite web|url=http://www.footprinttravelguides.com/latin-america/brazil/recife-and-the-northeast-coast/paraaba/joao-pessoa-and-around/|title=João Pessoa in Brazil|publisher=Footprint Travel Guides|accessdate=March 29, 2015}} ===Rail System=== The João Pessoa Urban Trains System is operated by [[Diesel engine|diesel]] components in only one railway line with a 30 km extension spanning 4 municipalities, João Pessoa, Cabedelo, Bayeux and Santa Rita, constituted by the Cabedelo / stretch, with 10 stations in operation, carrying around 10.1 thousand passengers per day. Composed of three locomotives and 17 passenger cars, forming two compositions that carry out 28 daily trips; the passengers can enjoy a pleasant, safe, economical and fast trip, besides contemplating beautiful rural landscapes in the urban area.{{cite web|url=https://www.cbtu.gov.br/index.php/pt/sistemas-cbtu/joao-pessoa/|title=João Pessoa|publisher=CBTU-Brazilian company of urban trains|accessdate=August 29, 2018}} ==Economy== The GDP for the city was [[Brazilian real|R$]] 14,841,805 (2010).{{cite book|url=http://www.ibge.gov.br/home/estatistica/economia/pibmunicipios/2005/tab01.pdf |title=GDP |publisher=[[Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics|IBGE]] |location=João Pessoa, Brazil |format=PDF |isbn=85-240-3919-1 |accessdate=July 18, 2007 |year=2005 |language=Portuguese |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081002024524/http://www.ibge.gov.br/home/estatistica/economia/pibmunicipios/2005/tab01.pdf |archivedate=October 2, 2008 |df= }} The per capita income for the city was [[Brazilian real|R$]] 19,284 (2010).{{cite book|url=http://www.ibge.gov.br/home/estatistica/economia/pibmunicipios/2005/tab01.pdf |title=per capita income |publisher=[[Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics|IBGE]] |location=João Pessoa, Brazil |format=PDF |isbn=85-240-3919-1 |accessdate=July 18, 2007 |year=2005 |language=Portuguese |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081002024524/http://www.ibge.gov.br/home/estatistica/economia/pibmunicipios/2005/tab01.pdf |archivedate=October 2, 2008 |df= }} [[File:Centro Histórico de João Pessoa - PB.JPG|thumb|right|Historic center of João Pessoa.]] [[File:Lagoa a noite.jpg|thumb|right| Solon de Lucena Park's lagoon at night in the northwestern region (the downtown zone or district).]] [[File:JoaoPessoatambaúNightView.JPG|thumb|right|João Pessoa's evening skyline (center-eastern region).]] [[File:JoaoPessoa ConventoSaoFrancisco.JPG|thumb|Saint Francis Church and Saint Anthony Convent (northern region).]] ==Sister cities== *{{flagdeco|USA}} [[Hartford]],{{cite web|url=https://www.cidade-brasil.com.br/municipio-joao-pessoa.html|title=MUNICIPALITY OF JOÃO PESSOA|accessdate=September 5, 2018|publisher=cidade-brasil}} United States. *{{flagdeco|USA}} [[Boca Raton]],{{cite web|url=http://www.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/secretaria-confirma-cooperacao-turistica-entre-joao-pessoa-e-cidade-dos-eua/|title=Secretariat confirms tourist cooperation between João Pessoa and US city|accessdate=September 5, 2018|date=August 31, 2017|author=Mônica Melo|publisher=MUNICIPAL CITY OF JOÃO PESSOA}} United States. *{{flagdeco|USA}} [[Pompano Beach]],{{cite web|url=https://gazetanews.com/palestra-bbg-cidades-irmas-joao-pessoa-pompano-beach/|title=Cities-Sisters – João Pessoa and Pompano Beach|accessdate=September 5, 2018|date=March 24, 2014|publisher= Gazeta News}} United States. ==Culture== In the crafts part, the city stands out for its creativity through the popular art, possessing some places to be visited. *"'''CREATIVE SPACE BARN'''":{{cite web|url=https://turismo.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/o-que-fazer/pontos-turisticos/artesanato/celeiro-espaco-criativo/|title=CREATIVE SPACE BARN|accessdate=August 30, 2018|publisher=Secretary of Tourism of the Municipality of João Pessoa}} The environment has an exhibition of pieces and works by more than 140 artisans and artists from Paraíba. The work of these artists can be visited by the public, who can also purchase the pieces. *"'''THE PARAIBANIAN CRAFT MARKET'''":{{cite web|url=https://turismo.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/o-que-fazer/pontos-turisticos/artesanato/mercado-de-artesanato-paraibano/|title=THE PARAIBANIAN CRAFT MARKET|accessdate=August 30, 2018|publisher=Secretary of Tourism of the Municipality of João Pessoa}} The building has more than 120 shops that sell the region's handicrafts. *"'''JÚLIO RAFAEL CRAFTS CENTER'''":{{cite web|url=https://turismo.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/o-que-fazer/pontos-turisticos/artesanato/centro-de-artesanato-de-tambau-julio-rafael/|title=JÚLIO RAFAEL CRAFTS CENTER|accessdate=August 30, 2018|publisher=Secretary of Tourism of the Municipality of João Pessoa}} The place has 20 stores where are tradized handicraft products of different typologies, such as renaissance, embroidery, colored cotton, leather, weaving. *"'''TAMBAÚ FAIRY'''":{{cite web|url=https://turismo.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/o-que-fazer/pontos-turisticos/artesanato/feirinha-de-tambau/|title=TAMBAÚ FAIRY|accessdate=August 30, 2018|publisher=Secretary of Tourism of the Municipality of João Pessoa}} The place has a large walk area where the shows and [[artistic]] and culture activities take place. The [[Fair]] is currently one of the main leisure options for visitors, tourists and residents of the capital. The Fair, has 45 boxes where the artisans sell their products and boxes where they sell typical foods of the Northeast. *"'''SERENE OF THE PENHA'''":{{cite web|url=https://turismo.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/o-que-fazer/pontos-turisticos/artesanato/sereias-da-penha/|title=SERENE OF THE PENHA|accessdate=August 30, 2018|publisher=Secretary of Tourism of the Municipality of João Pessoa}} The artisans who participate in the project produce biojóias with scales and fish leather. Pieces produced: biojoias (necklaces, bracelets and earrings), flowers, handbags, garments, arrangements and bouquets. Raw material: Shells, pearls, copper wires, fishing net wires and fish scales. The Penha Serene, seeks to provide improvements in the quality of life of the families of those who participate. The artisans have the talent to transform objects into true works of art.{{cite web|url=http://www.paraibacriativa.com.br/artista/sereias-da-penha/|title=Sereias da Penha|accessdate=August 30, 2018|publisher=Paraíba Criativa}} *"'''HOUSE OF THE PEOPLE ARTIST'''":{{cite web|url=http://www.paraibacriativa.com.br/artista/casa-do-artista-popular/|title=Museum Popular Artist's House|accessdate=August 29, 2018|publisher=Paraiba Criativa}} In the House of the Popular Artist the [[craft]]smen explore the variety of the crafts paraibano. In addition, the site houses the Craft Curatorship and spaces destined to the commercialization of the artisanal products and gastronomy of Paraíba. The collection consists of more than 1000 pieces that represent the genuine crafts of Paraíba, in 09 types: clay, wood, fibers, yarns, stones, metals, leather, indigenous handicrafts and recycled material. The space promotes the effective integration of the artisan activity with the tourist activity, contributing to the preservation of the manual arts that bring traces of the history, beliefs, customs and socio-cultural traditions of Paraíba. ==Tourism== [[File:Picaozinho.jpg|thumb|Picãozinho]] [[File:Peixes_recifais.jpg|thumb|Reef fish found on the Picãozinho reef.]] *'''Picãozinho''':{{cite web|url=https://turismo.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/o-que-fazer/pontos-turisticos/praias-e-piscinas-naturais/picaozinho/|title=PICÃOZINHO|accessdate=September 5, 2018|publisher=Secretary of Tourism of the Municipality of João Pessoa}} It is one of the most important sights of the city. São Reef Formation, located about 1,500 meters from Tambaú beach, on the coast of João Pessoa. *'''Natural Pools of Seixas Beach''':{{cite web|url=https://turismo.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/o-que-fazer/pontos-turisticos/praias-e-piscinas-naturais/piscinas-naturais-do-seixas/|title=SEIXAS NATURAL SWIMMING POOLS|accessdate=September 5, 2018|publisher=Secretary of Tourism of the Municipality of João Pessoa}} The Seixas Natural Pools, where we find hundreds of species of fish, seaweed, reptiles (sea turtles), mollusks, crustaceans and other marine organisms. [[File:Por_do_sol_Praia_do_Jacaré_-_JP.jpg|thumb|sunset at jacare beach]] *'''Sunset on Jacaré beach''':{{cite web|url=https://turismo.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/o-que-fazer/pontos-turisticos/praias-e-piscinas-naturais/por-do-jacare/|title=PÔR DO SOL DO JACARÉ |accessdate=September 5, 2018|publisher=Secretary of Tourism of the Municipality of João Pessoa}} Every day at 5:00 pm, when the sun begins to set, illuminating the waters of the Paraíba River, the saxophonist Jurandy do Sax, in a boat, performs the Ravel Bolero. At 6 pm another musician performs the 'Ave Maria'. [[File:Praia da Penha - João Pessoa, Paraíba, Brasil.jpg|thumb|penha of beach]] *'''Penha of Beach''':{{cite web|url=https://turismo.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/o-que-fazer/pontos-turisticos/praias-e-piscinas-naturais/praia-da-penha/|title=Penha Beach |accessdate=September 5, 2018|publisher=Secretary of Tourism of the Municipality of João Pessoa}} The name of this traditional beach derives from the symbol of one of the greatest religious events in Brazil: the Chapel of Our Lady of Penha. For more than 250 years, thousands of faithful have been accompanying the Penha Procession through the streets of João Pessoa. *'''Beach of the Sun''':{{cite web|url=https://turismo.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/o-que-fazer/pontos-turisticos/praias-e-piscinas-naturais/praia-do-sol/|title=Beach of the Sun |accessdate=September 5, 2018|publisher=Secretary of Tourism of the Municipality of João Pessoa}} Between beautiful cliffs and the mouths of rivers and mangroves, there are reefs, corals, light waves and a fine stretch of white sand. *'''Manaira Beach''':{{cite web|url=https://turismo.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/o-que-fazer/pontos-turisticos/praias-e-piscinas-naturais/praia-de-manaira/|title=MANAIR BEACH |accessdate=September 5, 2018|publisher=Secretary of Tourism of the Municipality of João Pessoa}} It is in the most economically developed neighborhood of Joao Pessoa. The sidewalk foot is commonly used for physical activities and well frequented by tourists and locals who enjoy the unique landscape. *'''Beach Tambaú''':{{cite web|url=https://turismo.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/o-que-fazer/pontos-turisticos/praias-e-piscinas-naturais/praia-de-tambau/|title=Beach Tambaú |accessdate=September 5, 2018|publisher=Secretary of Tourism of the Municipality of João Pessoa}} Synonymous with beauty and excitement, the sands of Praia de Tambaú are one of the busiest in Joao Pessoa. The various bars, restaurants and venues with live music are an additional attraction for those who want to enjoy one of the most beautiful beaches in the city. The handicraft market and the Tambaú Fair are a must stop for anyone visiting the neighborhood. The practice of diving is perfect for those who want to enjoy this paradise more closely. [[File:Praia de Cabo Branco - panoramio.jpg|thumb|cabo branco beach]] *'''Cabo Branco Beach''':{{cite web|url=https://turismo.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/o-que-fazer/pontos-turisticos/praias-e-piscinas-naturais/praia-de-tambau/|title=CAPE WHITE BEACH |accessdate=September 5, 2018|publisher=Secretary of Tourism of the Municipality of João Pessoa}} Located in one of the noblest districts of the city, the beach, neighboring Tambaú, is part of the busiest area of the personal border. There are numerous restaurants, hotels, snack bars and residences that coexist harmoniously with the environment and make Cabo Branco one of the most sought after destinations in the city. From the barrier of Cabo Branco, where the Lighthouse of the same name is located, we have one of the most beautiful landscapes in Brazil. *'''Bessa Beach''':{{cite web|url=https://turismo.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/o-que-fazer/pontos-turisticos/praias-e-piscinas-naturais/praia-do-bessa/|title=Beach Bessa |accessdate=September 5, 2018|publisher=Secretary of Tourism of the Municipality of João Pessoa}} In the extreme north of João Pessoa, with 5.3 km of white sands and beats, besides green and calm waters, reefs and coconut trees, beach Bessa is one of the most sought after by tourists. **'''Caribessa''' : A few kilometers from the beach, in the middle of 4 km of preserved corals, the stretch without waves near the edge of Bessa, known by tourists and locals as "Caribessa" due to its beautiful calm waters, is rich in marine diversity, being a perfect environment for the preservation of the ecosystem. Whether via kayak or stand up paddle, anyone who visits the "Caribessa" is always in touch with the best of [[nature]]. *'''Jacarapé Beach''':{{cite web|url=https://turismo.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/o-que-fazer/pontos-turisticos/praias-e-piscinas-naturais/praia-de-jacarape/|title=JACARAPÉ BEACH |accessdate=September 5, 2018|publisher=Secretary of Tourism of the Municipality of João Pessoa}} The native vegetation, the [[tranquility]] of the place and the soft sound of the weak waves breaking on the coast, make this part of the personal coast the perfect destination for your next trip. *'''Gramame Bar Beach''':{{cite web|url=https://turismo.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/o-que-fazer/pontos-turisticos/praias-e-piscinas-naturais/praia-de-barra-de-gramame/|title=GRAMAME BAR BEACH |accessdate=September 5, 2018|publisher=Secretary of Tourism of the Municipality of João Pessoa}} Beach more south of the coast of João Pessoa, Barra de Gramame is the scene of the encounter between the river and the sea. The formation of reefs in its extension guarantees a great tour to whoever visits it, even if it is an open sea beach. Dunes, mangroves and raft or kayak tours complement the experience of the visit. [[File:Joao Pessoa-PB Praia Ponta do Seixas.jpg|thumb|Seixas beach]] *'''Seixas Beach''':{{cite web|url=https://turismo.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/o-que-fazer/pontos-turisticos/praias-e-piscinas-naturais/praia-do-seixas/|title=Seixas Beach |accessdate=September 5, 2018|publisher=Secretary of Tourism of the Municipality of João Pessoa}} In this beach is the Eastern End of the Americas. Nationally known as the portion of land closest to the African continent, Praia do Seixas. *'''[[Centro de Convenções Poeta Ronaldo Cunha Lima|Convention Center Poet Ronaldo Cunha Lima]]'''{{cite web|url=http://www.cecon.pb.gov.br/en/sobre/|title=ABOUT THE CENTER|accessdate=October 30, 2018|publisher=Government of Paraiba}} : The convention center of João Pessoa was designed to be one of the most modern in the country, with all the necessary equipment to carry out major projects. Its structure consists of 4 main buildings the Lookout Tower, the Congress and Convention Hall and the Pedra do Reino Theater. [[File:PB - Praia Fluvial do Jacaré - Por do Sol - Cabedelo 1.jpg|thumb|Sunset Jacaré beach]] ==Museums== [[File:Pôr-do-sol - Hotel Globo - panoramio.jpg|thumb|Sunset Hotel Globe]] Source: *''Museu Sacro e de Arte Popular'', within the São Francisco church. *''Espaço Cultural José Lins do Rego''. A cultural centre including history and science museums. *''City Museum''. The former Casa da Pólvora, an old gunpowder store. *''Museu Fotográfico Walfredo Rodríguez''. *''Bica Natural History Museum[http://www.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/museu-de-historia-natural-da-bica-oferece-informacoes-sobre-meio-ambiente/ Bica Natural History Museum]''. *''Museum Foundation house of Jose Américo''.[http://www.museuvirtualjoseamerico.pb.gov.br/conteudo.php?pg=museu/ Museum Foundation house of Jose Américo] *''Hotel Globo Museum'':{{cite web|url=http://www.paraibacriativa.com.br/artista/hotel-globo/Hotel|title=Hotel Globo|accessdate=August 30, 2018|publisher=Paraiba Criativa}} Formerly a luxury hotel in the city, it consists of two buildings of eclectic style, and its lines are influenced by Neo-classical, Art, Nouveau and Art Deco styles. Today it functions as a museum, where it houses the permanent exhibition of part of the furniture of the Hotel, in addition to a collection of popular art, is much visited for the appreciation of the beautiful view of the Sanhauá River and the sunset seen from its garden. [[File:Vista do Hotel Globo para o Rio Sanhauá.jpg|thumb|View from Hotel Globo to the Rio Sanhauá]] =Sports= ==Stadiums== *[[Almeidão|José Américo de Almeida Filho]] Stadium *[[Estádio da Graça|Stadium of Grace]] ==Soccer== João Pessoa provides visitors and residents with various sport activities. *[[Botafogo Futebol Clube (PB)|Botafogo Futebol Clube]] *[[Auto Esporte Clube|Auto Esporte]] *[[Centro Sportivo Paraibano|CSP]] ==American Football== *'''João Pessoa Espectros''':{{cite web|url=http://globoesporte.globo.com/pb/futebol-americano/noticia/2017/01/10-anos-de-espectros-passeie-pela-historia-do-time-partir-de-seus-vultos.html|title=10 years of Espectros: review in photos the decade of the best team in the Northeast|accessdate= September 5, 2018|date= January 2, 2017|author= Hévilla Wanderley|publisher= Globo Esporte}} It is a football team, has a national title, seven regional and three state. Considered the best football team in the northeastern region of Brazil.{{cite web|url=http://globoesporte.globo.com/pb/futebol-americano/noticia/2017/01/10-anos-de-espectros-reveja-em-fotos-decada-do-melhor-time-do-nordeste.html|title=10 anos de Espectros: passeie pela história do time a partir de seus vultos|accessdate=September 5, 2018|date=January 4, 2017|author= Hévilla Wanderley|publisher= Globo Esporte}} ==Kayaking== Very Realized on Bessa beach, To reach the 4km of coral in the blue sea of the "Caribessa", tourists and practitioners can admire the beauties around it, kayaking will be a special reason to slowly enjoy every beautiful second that the nature of the city of [[João Pessoa,_Paraíba|João Pessoa]] offers{{cite web|url=https://turismo.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/o-que-fazer/esportes/caiaque/|title=Caiaque|accessdate= October 2, 2018|publisher= Secretary of Tourism of the Municipality of João Pessoa}}. ==Windsurfing== [[File:Windsurf.JPG|thumb|The practice of windsurfing]] The practice of [[windsurfing]] on the beautiful beaches of the city of [[João Pessoa,_Paraíba|João Pessoa]], yields an incredible experience in maximum contact with nature{{cite web|url=https://turismo.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/o-que-fazer/esportes/windsurf/|title=windsurf|accessdate= October 2, 2018|publisher= Secretary of Tourism of the Municipality of João Pessoa}}. ==Sailing== [[File:J-24_yacht_racing,_Sydney_Harbour.jpg|thumb|the practice of Sailing]] Realized in the Natural Pools of [[Ponta do Seixas|Seixas beach]], on the most extreme eastern beach of the americas, where the sun rises first, the tourist contemplates the harmony between the blue of the sky and the green of the sea in the capital of Paraíba, and reveals fascinating scenarios{{cite web|url=https://turismo.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/o-que-fazer/esportes/vela/|title=VELA|accessdate= October 2, 2018|publisher= Secretary of Tourism of the Municipality of João Pessoa}}. ==Surfing== [[File:Surfers_at_Mavericks.jpg|thumb|the practice of Surfing]] Cradle of great surfers with national prominence, the [[Paraíba]] has winning athletes in the most important disputes of the sport{{cite web|url=https://turismo.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/o-que-fazer/esportes/surf/|title=SURF|accessdate= October 2, 2018|publisher= Secretary of Tourism of the Municipality of João Pessoa}}. ==Standup paddleboarding== It is usually done on the beach of Bessa, in the quiet part known as caribessa, paddling on a surfboard, it is used on foot all that the sea can offer, and contemplated the beauties of one of the most beautiful sights of [[João Pessoa,_Paraíba|João Pessoa]]{{cite web|url=https://turismo.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/o-que-fazer/esportes/stand-up-paddle/|title=stand up paddle|accessdate= October 2, 2018|publisher= Secretary of Tourism of the Municipality of João Pessoa}}. ==Diving== The [[coastline]] of [[João Pessoa,_Paraíba|João Pessoa]], home to three of the most visited shipwrecks in the Northeast, are mainly sought after by [[nautical]] tourism enthusiasts and divers adventurers: ''Queimado'', ''Alice'' and ''Alvarenga'' are considered of rare beauty and still maintain intact areas taken by algae and living beings from the bottom of the sea{{cite web|url=https://turismo.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/o-que-fazer/esportes/surf/|title=mergulho|accessdate= October 2, 2018|publisher= Secretary of Tourism of the Municipality of João Pessoa}}. [[File:Buzo.jpg|thumb|scuba diving practice]] *'''Alvarenga Shipwreck''' : It is a type of vessel that was used to transport supplies to ships and wrecked 6 miles from the tip of '''''Bessa's beach''''', 20 meters deep. It remains whole measuring 20 meters in length by 5 meters in the mouth. It is possible to penetrate the small bow and stern [[compartment (ship)|compartment]]s safely. On the prow we can still see the winch that picked up the anchor. It is also common to find large stingrays and large shoals of fish, such as the top cock and the hook{{cite web|url=https://turismo.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/o-que-fazer/esportes/surf/|title=Naufrágio Alvarenga|accessdate= October 2, 2018|publisher= Secretary of Tourism of the Municipality of João Pessoa}}. *'''Burnt Shipwreck''' : The Erie J.N.Y is an American steam of 2,000 tons. He had left Rio de Janeiro with 24,900 bags of coffee destined for the United States. On January 2, 1873, at 2 am, it caught fire and sank (so it was known as "Burned"). Passengers and crew were saved. Today it is 17 meters deep, five miles from the tip of '''''Bessa beach''''', in [[João_Pessoa,_Paraíba|João Pessoa]] and its debris measures about 100 meters long by 15 meters wide (approximately 12 meters of mouth). There remains among the wrecks a large machine shaft that ends in a large propeller. The visibility of the water can reach 30 meters in the summer, but on average stays between 10 and 20 meters. It is the most visited by divers. It is considered the most significant [[shipwreck]] in the world, because it has its [[rectangular]] boilers and it is home to more than 50% of the [[marine biology|marine]] species found in [[Paraíba]]{{cite web|url=https://turismo.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/o-que-fazer/esportes/surf/|title=Naufrágio Queimado|accessdate= October 2, 2018|publisher= Secretary of Tourism of the Municipality of João Pessoa}}. *'''Wreck Alice''': Alice is a Brazilian steam which was built in 1866 and measured 53 meters long by 6.6 meters. He was chartered by the government to transport Brazilian troops in the [[Paraguayan_War|Paraguayan war]]. On March 30, 1869, Prince Emperor Gaston d'Orleans ([[Count d'Eu]]) took his place to take command of the Brazilian Army; Alice was [[shipwreck]]ed in 1911. Today it is 3.5 miles from the tip of '''''Bessa beach''''' and is 12 meters deep. The bow is its most entire part, 7.5 meters from the surface{{cite web|url=https://turismo.joaopessoa.pb.gov.br/o-que-fazer/esportes/surf/|title=Naufrágio Alice|accessdate= October 2, 2018|publisher= Secretary of Tourism of the Municipality of João Pessoa}}. =References= {{Reflist|2}} =External links= {{sisterlinks|João Pessoa}} * {{Wikivoyage-inline|João Pessoa}} * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V1nrP8Ksti8 Official Promotional video of João Pessoa | English] {{Brazil topics}} {{Capitals of Brazilian states}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Joao Pessoa}} [[Category:João Pessoa| ]] [[Category:1585 establishments in the Portuguese Empire]] [[Category:Populated places established in 1585]] [[Category:UNESCO Creative Cities Network]]

page.title: Library damage resulting from the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake

revision.text:
[[Image:Meulaboh.jpg|thumb|right|An aerial view of the coastal city of Meulaboh, Indonesia, after the tsunami. The public library in Meulaboh was completely destroyed.]] '''Library damage resulting from the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake''' has been reported in six Asian countries. On December 26, the massive [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake]] struck off the northwest coast of the [[Indonesia]]n island of [[Sumatra]]. The resulting [[tsunami]]s killed more than 180,000 people. In addition to the loss of human lives, cultural institutions were destroyed in several Asian nations. [[Library|Libraries]] on the Eastern coast of [[Sri Lanka]] and the northern province of [[Aceh]] on Sumatra were most severely affected by the disaster.
== India == {{2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami}} Damage to libraries in [[India]] has not been well documented. Water damage was reported at Madras University Library in [[Chennai]].<ref>[http://www.ala.org/ala/alonline/currentnews/newsarchive/2005abc/january2005ab/tsunami.htm American Library Association. (2005). South Asian libraries hit hard by tsunami. ''American Libraries.''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050919154444/http://www.ala.org/ala/alonline/currentnews/newsarchive/2005abc/january2005ab/tsunami.htm |date=2005-09-19 }} Retrieved October 28, 2006</ref> The [[Asian Development Bank]] reports extensive damage to schools in the Indian states of [[Kerala]] and [[Tamil Nadu]]. A government assessment found that 252 schools in Tamil Nadu need complete reconstruction, 19 need major repairs and 49 need minor repairs.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.adb.org/features/2004-earthquake-and-tsunami-day-suffering-brought-world-together |title=Asian Development Bank, United Nations and World Bank. (2005, March 8). ''India post tsunami recovery program: Preliminary Damage and Needs Assessment.'' |access-date=2015-01-06 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150106104239/http://www.adb.org/features/2004-earthquake-and-tsunami-day-suffering-brought-world-together |archive-date=2015-01-06 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
In the [[Andaman islands|Andaman]] and [[Nicobar Islands]], 78 teachers are listed as killed or missing. Further, 25 percent of primary schools, 33 percent of upper primary schools, and 31 percent of senior secondary schools were seriously damaged, indicating that school libraries in the region also suffered damage.<ref>UNICEF. ''Children eager to return to schools in Andaman and Nicobar Islands.'' Retrieved December 5, 2007, from http://www.unicef.org/infobycountry/index_25059.html ({{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607215010/http://www.unicef.org/infobycountry/index_25059.html |date=June 7, 2011 }})</ref>
== Indonesia == The Sumatran province of [[Aceh]] was severely damaged by the earthquake and resulting tsunami. An estimated 167,736 Indonesians were killed and 25% of Achenese lost their source of livelihood.<ref>UN Office of the Special Envoy for Tsunami Recovery. ''Human toll.'' Retrieved October 28, 2006, from http://www.tsunamispecialenvoy.org/country/humantoll.asp ({{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070703224410/http://www.tsunamispecialenvoy.org/country/humantoll.asp |date=July 3, 2007 }})</ref> [[Banda Aceh]], Aceh's capital, was the closest major city to the earthquake's epicenter, and many of its major libraries suffered extensive damage.<ref>[http://www.ifla.org/V/press/tsunami-Indonesia1.htm International Federation of Library Associations and Institutions (IFLA). (2005, March 29)] Retrieved October 18, 2006</ref>
The Aceh Provincial Library (BPD) was inundated with three meters of water. Twenty three staff members were killed, including the library's director, Bachtiar Azis, who is listed as missing along with his family. In addition to loss of life, the BPD suffered physical damage and a near total loss of its collection. Concrete and steel fences surrounding the two-story building were mostly destroyed, however, the building itself remained standing. All library materials housed on the first floor were swept away by the waves and the floor was covered in 30 cm.-thick mud. These lost materials comprise most of its children, young adult and adult collections. The water did not reach the second floor, but looting resulted in the loss of most materials and equipment. A collection of books received under legal deposit and housed on the second floor was left undisturbed and survived the disaster and looting intact.<ref name="ALA | Tsunami-Report from Indonesia">[http://www.ala.org/ala/aboutala/offices/iro/iroactivities/tsunamiindonesianreport.cfm ALA | Tsunami-Report from Indonesia<!-- Bot generated title -->] ( {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/64Dce1FRO?url=http://www.ala.org/ala/aboutala/offices/iro/iroactivities/tsunamiindonesianreport.cfm |date=December 26, 2011 }})</ref> Despite these losses, the BPD reopened to the public in May 2005.<ref>McKenzie, Amelia. Books for Aceh project. ''Gateways.'' Retrieved December 5, 2007, from {{cite web |url=http://www.nla.gov.au/pub/gateways/issues/77/story15.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-12-26 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/64DfWBdqa?url=http://www.nla.gov.au/pub/gateways/issues/77/story15.html |archivedate=December 26, 2011 |df= }} ()</ref> As of August 2005, repairs were still being made to the building, the library lacked computers for its ''warintek'' (information technology section), and most areas of the library needed furnishing and collection replacement.
Of Aceh's eight [[public library|public libraries]], two were completely destroyed. These libraries were located in the hard-hit cities of [[Meulaboh]] and [[Sigli]].<ref name="Baba, Zawiyah 2005 PPM">Baba, Zawiyah, Hasbullah Atan, Rohani Rustam, and Abdul Hamid Abdul Rahman. (2005). Report of Librarians' Association of Malaysia (PPM) Iqra' Mission to Aceh, North Sumatra, Indonesia, 2–5 August 2005. ''Alexandria'',17(3):167–175.</ref>
Mobile library units, or ''perpustakaan keliling'', are used to serve rural areas of Aceh. Days before the earthquake and tsunami, the BPD had received two newly built mobile library units from the [[National Library of Indonesia]]. Both of these were destroyed along with the rest of the mobile libraries parked on the BPD's carport. In July 2005, the National Library donated two replacement mobile units, however the new BPD director noted that further units were needed to adequately serve outlying regions of the province.<ref name="ALA | Tsunami-Report from Indonesia"/><ref name="Baba, Zawiyah 2005 PPM"/>
The [[Aceh Documentation and Information Center]], known for its collection of rare books and manuscripts chronicling the heritage of Aceh, was completely destroyed. Only half of the building remained standing, and the entire collection was swept away. A team from the [[National Library of Indonesia]] visiting in January 2005 was able to salvage only three books and one sheet of the genealogy of the [[Muslim]] kings of Aceh. These were taken to [[Jakarta]] for restoration.<ref name="ALA | Tsunami-Report from Indonesia"/>
The [[Provincial Archives Agency]] lost 80 percent of the photographs in its collection.<ref name=Utomo>[http://www.ica.org/biblio/Djoko%20Utomo%20abstract%20ENG_2.pdf Utomo, Djoko. ''Recovering from the tsunami: The consequences for record keeping.''] {{dead link|date=December 2011}}</ref> The Secretariat Office of the Aceh Province lost 160 boxes of records.<ref name=Utomo/>
The Aceh branch of the National Land Register Agency was inundated with water. Roughly 629 boxes of materials certifying individual land ownership in the province were damaged. Due to the efforts of a team of conservators from Japan and archivists from the National Archives in Jakarta, many of these land register documents were preserved.<ref>Sakamoto, Isamu. (2005). Disaster from great earthquake off Sumatra and subsequent tsunamis including damage to cultural heritage. ''International Preservation News,'' 36:16–19.</ref>
Damage to school libraries has not been well documented. The Indonesia National Library reports that SMA 1, a high school in Banda Aceh, was not damaged by flood waters as it is located on the second floor, however, did experience some earthquake damage. Overall, 2,364 teachers and staff members were killed and 2,240 schools were destroyed on Sumatra and its outlying islands.<ref>UN Office of the Special Envoy for Tsunami Recovery. ''Indonesia.'' Retrieved October 28, 2006, from http://www.tsunamispecialenvoy.org/country/indonesia.asp ({{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070314171442/http://www.tsunamispecialenvoy.org/country/indonesia.asp |date=March 14, 2007 }})</ref>
The Central Library at the Ar-Raniri Institute for Islamic Studies, a public Islamic University in Banda Aceh, lost its information servers due to theft and seawater damage.<ref>Sakamoto, Isamu. (2005, December 2005). ''One step forward-relief work for damaged documents at Aceh, Indonesia.'' Retrieved October 28, 2006, from {{cite web |url=http://www.ndl.go.jp/en/iflapac/pdf/sakamoto.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-12-26 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/64DflexHN?url=http://www.ndl.go.jp/en/iflapac/pdf/sakamoto.pdf |archivedate=December 26, 2011 |df= }} ()</ref>
Baiturrahman Grand Mosque Library in Banda Aceh lost its entire collection. Due to the [[mosque|mosque's]] central location and importance to the community, a concerted effort was made to clear and repair this complex of buildings immediately after the tsunami. As of August 2005 the library had reopened with 1,200 books in its collection.<ref name="ALA | Tsunami-Report from Indonesia"/> The library of the Agricultural Information Institute of Banda Aceh was inundated with water from the tsunami but its physical structure remained intact.<ref name="ALA | Tsunami-Report from Indonesia"/><ref>[http://www.lib.washington.edu/SoutheastAsia/Acehlibs.html Libraries in Jeopardy from the Aceh Tsunami] ( {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/64Dg1cSMD?url=http://www.lib.washington.edu/SoutheastAsia/Acehlibs.html |date=December 26, 2011 }})</ref>
The Library and Museum of the Ali Hasymy Educational Foundation survived intact as the tsunami did not reach this area of Banda Aceh.<ref name="ALA | Tsunami-Report from Indonesia"/>
== Malaysia == According to a Malaysian professor of [[library science]], damage to libraries was minimal in [[Malaysia]].<ref>Whelan, Debra Lau. (2005). Libraries in tsunami's path need aid. ''School Library Journal.'' Available from {{cite web |url=http://www.schoollibraryjournal.com/article/CA499367.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-12-26 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/64DgDjRYp?url=http://www.schoollibraryjournal.com/article/CA499367.html |archivedate=December 26, 2011 |df= }} ()</ref>
== Maldives == All of the 199 inhabited islands comprising the [[Maldives]] atolls were affected by the tsunami.<ref name="portal.unesco.org">[http://portal.unesco.org/education/en/ev.php-URL_ID=38155&URL_DO=DO_TOPIC&URL_SECTION=201.html UNESCO | Education – The Maldives was the only country where the effects of the tsunami were felt across the entire country rather than in certain parts or regions/atolls. 82 people are reported dead and 26 are missing<!-- Bot generated title -->] ( {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/64DeUibxn?url=http://portal.unesco.org/education/en/ev.php-URL_ID%3D38155%26URL_DO%3DDO_TOPIC%26URL_SECTION%3D201.html |date=December 26, 2011 }})</ref> The Maldives Library Association was not able to survey all public libraries across the atoll, however, a representative indicated some libraries were completely destroyed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ala.org/ala/aboutala/offices/iro/iroactivities/destructionmaldiveslib.cfm |title=Destruction of Maldives Libraries |publisher=ALA |date=2004-12-26 |accessdate=2012-12-24}}</ref>
Forty-six percent of schools in the Maldives were damaged, and nine schools were completely destroyed.<ref name="portal.unesco.org"/>
== Thailand == Damage to libraries in [[Thailand]] has not been well documented. The Ministry of Education has reported that five schools were completely destroyed and 51 schools were damaged.<ref>Asian Disaster Preparedness Center. ''The economic impact of the 26 December 2004 earthquake & Indian Ocean tsunami in Thailand.'' Retrieved October 18, 2006, from {{cite web |url=http://www.adpc.net/maininforesource/dms/thailand_assessmentreport.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-12-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/64DgLQwNV?url=http://www.adpc.net/maininforesource/dms/thailand_assessmentreport.pdf |archivedate=December 26, 2011 |df= }} ()</ref>
== Sri Lanka == More than 35,000 [[Sri Lanka]]ns were killed and 516,000 people were displaced as a result of the tsunami.<ref>UN Office of the Special Envoy for Tsunami Recovery. ''Sri Lanka.'' Retrieved October 28, 2006, from http://www.tsunamispecialenvoy.org/country/srilanka.asp</ref> Roughly 60 percent of the coastal area of Sri Lanka was severely affected by the tsunami. Libraries across the country were damaged, and it is estimated that 1.2 million volumes of books and other reading materials were destroyed in the disaster. Out of the 950 public libraries in Sri Lanka, 55 libraries were affected and 28 were completely destroyed.<ref name="ndl.go.jp">{{cite web|url=http://www.ndl.go.jp/en/iflapac/pdf/amarasiri.pdf |title=Amarasiri, Upali. (2005). ''Tsunami affected libraries in Sri Lanka: Rebuilding process and challenges.'' |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2012-12-24}}</ref> Several libraries were used as refuge centres or hospitals in the aftermath of the tsunami, and surviving furniture and collections suffered as a result.
One estimate of damage to school libraries in Sri Lanka indicates that of the 9,790 schools in the country, 182 schools were directly affected by the tsunami and an additional 282 schools were damaged because of their use as refugee camps after the tsunami.<ref name="ndl.go.jp"/> While not all of these schools had a full-fledged library, most had a book closet or other collection of materials. At least 165 school libraries were damaged by the tsunami.<ref>Premila Gamage and Maria Cotera. (2005). Rising from the rubble: The Sri Lanka Library Association rehabilitation project. ''Impact:''50-52.</ref> Compounding the damage, many schools had large collection of textbooks on hand for distribution to students at the beginning of the school year in January. Damage reports range from furniture damage to lost collections to complete destruction of the physical building...
Sri Lankan government departments lost public records to the tsunami. In the Southern province, all electoral registers were destroyed, along with 600,000 land deeds from the Department of the Surveyor General.<ref>Amarasiri, Upali. (2005). Rising from the wreckage: Development of tsunami-affected libraries in Sri Lanka. ''IFLA News,'' 31(4):307–314.</ref>
Sixty-eight libraries affiliated with religious institutions and at least three museums were damaged by the tsunami.<ref>Premila Gemage and Maria Cotera. (2005). Rising from the rubble: The Sri Lanka Library Association rehabilitation project. ''Impact:''50-52.</ref> Many of these libraries were attached to [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] [[temple]]s and contained valuable collections of palm leaf manuscripts and documents relating to [[Ayurveda]], the Indian medical tradition adopted in ancient Sri Lanka.<ref name="ndl.go.jp"/>
The [[National Maritime Museum (Galle)|National Maritime Museum]] in [[Galle]] lost 90 percent of its collection, mostly artifacts salvaged from underwater wrecks and archaeology sites. The museum also lost all of its computers and other technical equipment.<ref>International Federation of Library Associations and Institutions (IFLA). (2005, January 27). ''Libraries completely missing: Tsunami and Sri Lanka's East Coast.'' Retrieved October 18, 2006, from {{cite web |url=http://www.ifla.org/V/press/tsunami-SriLanka-report7.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-11-02 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/64DggbmKB?url=http://archive.ifla.org/V/press/tsunami-SriLanka-report7.htm |archivedate=December 26, 2011 |df= }} ()</ref> The collection housed in the Martin Wickramasinghe Folk Museum of Koggala survived relatively unscathed, however the children's library attached to the museum was severely damaged along with most of the museum's furniture. The Maritime Archaeology Unit of the Central Cultural Fund was also severely damaged, resulting in the loss of artifacts from an 18th-century Dutch shipwreck that were eventually to be donated to a museum.<ref>Gamage, Premila. (2005). Tsunami devastates Sri Lankan libraries. ''International Leads,'' 19(1):1–2.</ref>
In the weeks following the disaster, the [[International Federation of Library Associations and Institutions]] cooperated with UNESCO, the [[Sri Lanka Library Association]], the National Library and Documentation Center of Sri Lanka and other organizations to create the Sri Lanka Disaster Management Committee for Libraries, Information Services and Archives (SL DMC-LISA). The committee worked to secure funding for temporary libraries and computer equipment and began reviewing architectural plans for rebuilding libraries. Further initiatives were developed to encourage "twinning" or pairing of Sri Lankan libraries with donors.<ref>Ashling, Jim. (2005). Support for libraries in tsunami aftermath. ''International Report:''24-25.</ref>
In addition to working with the disaster committee, the Sri Lanka Library Association targeted five libraries for rebuilding with the intent of creating model institutions. As of 2006, three of these libraries had re-opened, while progress on the other two was delayed due to political instability in the region.<ref>[http://www.slla.org.lk/naclis-2006/pub/annual%20rep2006.pdf Sri Lanka Library Association – Annual Report 2005-2006] ({{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927090423/http://www.slla.org.lk/naclis-2006/pub/annual%20rep2006.pdf |date=September 27, 2007 }})</ref>

{{more footnotes|date=March 2010}} {{Linguistic_typology topics}}
'''Linguistic typology''' is a field of [[linguistics]] that studies and classifies languages according to their structural and functional features. Its aim is to describe and explain the common properties and the structural diversity of the world's languages.<ref name=":0" /> Its subdisciplines include, but are not limited to: qualitative typology, which deals with the issue of comparing languages and within-language variance; quantitative typology, which deals with the distribution of structural patterns in the world’s languages; theoretical typology, which explains these distributions; syntactic typology, which deals with word order, word form, and word choice; and lexical typology, which deals with language vocabulary.
==Qualitative typology== Qualitative typology develops cross-linguistically viable notions or types that provide a framework for the description and comparison of individual languages. A few examples appear below.
===Typological systems=== ====Subject–verb–object positioning==== {{main|Word order}} One set of types reflects the basic order of [[subject (grammar)|subject]], [[verb]], and [[direct object]] in sentences:
* [[Object–subject–verb]] * [[Object–verb–subject]] * [[Subject–verb–object]] * [[Subject–object–verb]] * [[Verb–subject–object]] * [[Verb–object–subject]]
These labels usually appear abbreviated as "SVO" and so forth, and may be called "typologies" of the languages to which they apply. The most commonly attested word orders are SOV and SVO while the least common orders are those that are object initial with OVS being the least common with only four attested instances.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Gell-Mann |first=Murray |last2=Ruhlen |first2=Merritt |date=2011-10-18 |title=The origin and evolution of word order |journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America |volume=108 |issue=42 |pages=17290–17295 |doi=10.1073/pnas.1113716108 |issn=0027-8424 |pmc=3198322 |pmid=21987807}}</ref>
In the 1980s, linguists began to question the relevance of geographical distribution of different values for various features of linguistic structure. They may have wanted to discover whether a particular grammatical structure found in one language is likewise found in another language in the same geographic location.<ref>Comrie, Bernard, et al. “Chapter Introduction.” WALS Online - Chapter Introduction, The World Atlas of Language Structures Online, 2013.</ref> Some languages split verbs into an auxiliary and an infinitive or participle, and put the subject and/or object between them. For instance, German ({{lang|de|Ich '''habe''' einen Fuchs im Wald '''gesehen'''}} - *"I have a fox in-the woods seen"), Dutch ({{lang|nl|Hans '''vermoedde''' dat Jan Marie '''zag leren zwemmen'''}} - *"Hans suspected that Jan Marie saw teach swim") and Welsh ({{lang|cy|'''Mae'''<nowiki>'</nowiki>r gwirio sillafu wedi'i '''gwblhau'''}} - *"Is the checking spelling after its to complete"). In this case, linguists base the typology on the non-analytic tenses (i.e. those sentences in which the verb is not split) or on the position of the auxiliary. German is thus SVO in main clauses and Welsh is VSO (and preposition phrases would go after the infinitive).
Many typologists{{Who|date=March 2017}} classify both German and Dutch as [[V2 word order|V2]] languages, as the verb invariantly occurs as the second element of a full clause.
Some languages allow varying degrees of freedom in their constituent order, posing a problem for their classification within the subject–verb–object schema. Languages with bound case markings for nouns, for example, tend to have more flexible word orders than languages where case is defined by position within a sentence or presence of a preposition.{{Example needed |date=May 2018}} To define a basic constituent order type in this case, one generally looks at frequency of different types in declarative affirmative main clauses in pragmatically neutral contexts, preferably with only old referents. Thus, for instance, Russian is widely considered an SVO language, as this is the most frequent constituent order under such conditions—all sorts of variations are possible, though, and occur in texts. In many inflected languages, such as Russian, Latin, and Greek, departures from the default word-orders are permissible but usually imply a shift in focus, an emphasis on the final element, or some special context. In the poetry of these languages, the word order may also shift freely to meet metrical demands. Additionally, freedom of word order may vary within the same language—for example, formal, literary, or archaizing varieties may have different, stricter, or more lenient constituent-order structures than an informal spoken variety of the same language.
On the other hand, when there is no clear preference under the described conditions, the language is considered to have "flexible constituent order" (a type unto itself).
An additional problem is that in languages without living speech communities, such as [[Latin]], [[Ancient Greek]], and [[Old Church Slavonic]], linguists have only written evidence, perhaps written in a poetic, formalizing, or archaic style that mischaracterizes the actual daily use of the language. The daily spoken language of [[Sophocles]] or [[Cicero]] might have exhibited a different or much more regular syntax than their written legacy indicates.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}}
====Morphosyntactic alignment==== {{main|Morphosyntactic alignment}} Another common classification distinguishes [[nominative–accusative language|nominative–accusative]] alignment patterns and [[Ergative–absolutive language|ergative–absolutive]] ones. In a language with [[noun case|cases]], the classification depends on whether the subject (S) of an intransitive verb has the same case as the agent (A) or the patient (P) of a transitive verb. If a language has no cases, but the word order is AVP or PVA, then a classification may reflect whether the subject of an intransitive verb appears on the same side as the agent or the patient of the transitive verb. Bickel (2011) has argued that alignment should be seen as a construction-specific property rather than a language-specific property.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.uni-leipzig.de/~bickel/research/papers/manifesto.pdf|title=What is typology? - a short note|last=Bickel|first=B.|date=|website=www.uni-leipzig.de|language=de|access-date=2017-03-06}}</ref>
Many languages show mixed accusative and ergative behaviour (for example: ergative morphology marking the verb arguments, on top of an accusative syntax). Other languages (called "[[active language]]s") have two types of intransitive verbs—some of them ("active verbs") join the subject in the same case as the agent of a transitive verb, and the rest ("stative verbs") join the subject in the same case as the patient{{Example needed|date=May 2018}}. Yet other languages behave ergatively only in some contexts (this "[[split ergativity]]" is often based on the grammatical person of the arguments or on the tense/aspect of the verb). For example, only some verbs in [[Georgian language|Georgian]] behave this way, and, as a rule, only while using the [[perfective]] (aorist).
====Phonological systems==== {{main|Phonology}} Linguistic typology also seeks to identify patterns in the structure and distribution of sound systems among the world's languages. This is accomplished by surveying and analyzing the relative frequencies of different phonological properties. These relative frequencies might, for example, be used to determine why contrastive voicing commonly occurs with plosives, as in English ''neat'' and ''need'', but occurs much more rarely among fricatives, such as the English ''niece'' and ''knees''. According to a worldwide sample of 637 languages,<ref name="Song, 2011">Song, J.J. (ed.) (2011). The Oxford Handbook of Linguistic Typology. Oxford: Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|978-0-19-928125-1}}.</ref> 62% have the voicing contrast in stops but only 35% have this in fricatives. In the vast majority of those cases, the absence of voicing contrast occurs because there is a lack of voiced fricatives and because all languages have some form of plosive, but there are languages with no fricatives. Below is a chart showing the breakdown of voicing properties among languages in the aforementioned sample. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Plosive Voicing ! colspan="3" | Fricative Voicing |- | | style="text-align: center;" | Yes | style="text-align: center;" | No | style="text-align: center;" | Total |- | Yes | style="text-align: center;" | 117 | style="text-align: center;" | 218 | 395 (62%) |- | No | style="text-align: center;" | 44 | style="text-align: center;" | 198 | 242 (38%) |- | Total | 221 (35%) | 416 (65%) | style="text-align: center;" | 637 |}<ref name="Song, 2011"/>
Languages worldwide also vary in the number of sounds they use. These languages can go from very small phonemic inventories ([[Rotokas language|Rotokas]] with six consonants and five vowels) to very large inventories ([[Taa language|!Xóõ]] with 128 consonants and 28 vowels). An interesting phonological observation found with this data is that the larger a consonant inventory a language has, the more likely it is to contain a sound from a defined set of complex consonants (clicks, glottalized consonants, doubly articulated labial-velar stops, lateral fricatives and affricates, uvular and pharyngeal consonants, and dental or alveolar non-sibilant fricatives). Of this list, only about 26% of languages in a survey<ref name="Song, 2011"/> of over 600 with small inventories (less than 19 consonants) contain a member of this set, while 51% of average languages (19-25) contain at least one member and 69% of large consonant inventories (greater than 25 consonants) contain a member of this set. It is then seen that complex consonants are in proportion to the size of the inventory.
Vowels contain a more modest number of phonemes, with the average being 5-6, which 51% of the languages in the survey have. About a third of the languages have larger than average vowel inventories. Most interesting though is the lack of relationship between consonant inventory size and vowel inventory size. Below is a chart showing this lack of predictability between consonant and vowel inventory sizes in relation to each other. {| class="wikitable" |- !Consonant Inventory ! colspan="4" | Vowel Quality Inventory |- | |style="text-align: center;" | Small |style="text-align: center;" | Average |style="text-align: center;" | Large |style="text-align: center;" | Total |- |Small |style="text-align: center;" | 47 |style="text-align: center;" | 153 |style="text-align: center;" | 65 |265 (39%) |- |Average |style="text-align: center;" | 34 |style="text-align: center;" | 105 |style="text-align: center;" | 98 |237 (35%) |- |Large |style="text-align: center;" | 34 |style="text-align: center;" | 87 |style="text-align: center;" | 57 |178 (26%) |- |Total |115 (17%) |345 (51%) |220 (32%) |style="text-align: center;" | 680 |}<ref name="Song, 2011"/>
==Quantitative typology== Quantitative typology deals with the distribution and co-occurrence of structural patterns in the languages of the world. Major types of non-chance distribution include:
* preferences (for instance, absolute and implicational [[linguistic universal|universals]], semantic maps, and [[implicational hierarchy|hierarchies]]) * correlations (for instance, areal patterns, such as with a [[Sprachbund]])
Linguistic universals are patterns that can be seen cross linguistically. Universals can either be absolute, meaning that every documented language exhibits this characteristic, or statistical, meaning that this characteristic is seen in most languages or is probable in most languages. Universals, both absolute and statistical can be unrestricted, meaning that they apply to most or all languages without any additional conditions. Conversely, both absolute and statistical universals can be restricted or implicational, meaning that a characteristic will be true on the condition of something else (if Y characteristic is true, then X characteristic is true).<ref>{{cite book|last1=Moravcsik|first1=Edith|title=Introducing Language Typology|date=2013|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge, London|page=9}}</ref>

The '''list of hoards in the Isle of Man''' comprises significant [[Archaeology|archaeological]] [[hoard]]s of coins, jewellery, precious and scrap metal objects and other valuable items discovered in the [[Isle of Man]]. It includes both hoards that were buried with the intention of retrieval at a later date (personal hoards, [[Foundry|founder's]] hoards, merchant's hoards, and hoards of loot), and also hoards of [[votive offering]]s which were not intended to be recovered at a later date, but excludes [[grave goods]] and single items found in isolation. The list is subdivided into sections according to archaeological and historical periods. {{GeoGroupTemplate}} ==Viking hoards== From the 9th to the 13th centuries the Isle of Man was part of the [[Viking]]-ruled [[Kingdom of the Isles]], and several significant hoards from this period have been found on the Isle of Man. Viking hoards generally comprise a mixture of silver coins, silver jewellery and [[hacksilver]] that has been taken in loot. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width: 100%" |- ! width="10%" | Hoard !! width="10%" | Image !! width="10%" | Date !! width="20%" | Place of discovery !! width="10%" | Year of discovery !! width="15%" | Current Location !! class="unsortable" width="25%" | Contents |- | Ballaquayle Hoard || [[File:British Museum Ballaquayle Hoard.jpg|100px|Selection of items from the Ballaquayle Hoard]] || {{sort|0975|late 10th century}} || {{sort|Isle of Man|Ballaquayle, [[Douglas, Isle of Man|Douglas]]}}

[[File:Mary Brodrick Egyptologist.jpg|thumbnail|upright|Mary Brodrick]] Dr. '''Mary (May) Brodrick''' [[F.R.G.S.]] (1858 – 13 July 1933) was a British [[archaeologist]] and [[Egyptologist]] who was one of the first female excavators in Egypt. She persisted in her studies despite the initial opposition of her tutors and fellow students and achieved distinction in her field. The ''[[Daily Mail]]'' described her in 1906 as "perhaps the greatest lady Egyptologist of the day".<ref>''Daily Mail'', 26 November 1906. Quoted in Janssen.</ref>
== Early life == Brodrick was born at 18 Navarino Terrace,<ref name=ODNB>[http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/48602 Brodrick, Mary (1858–1933).] David Gill, ''[[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]]'', Oxford University Press. Retrieved 2 February 2015. {{subscription required}}</ref> [[Dalston]], Middlesex (now London), on 5 April 1858,<ref name=ODNB/> the eldest daughter of Thomas and Mary Brodrick. Thomas Brodrick was a solicitor and the [[United Kingdom Census 1861|1861 census]] shows the family living within the Liberty of the Close, in the grounds of [[Salisbury Cathedral]], Wiltshire. Mary Brodrick had sisters Edith and Ethel.<ref>"1861 England, Wales & Scotland Census Transcription". ''findmypast''. Retrieved 14 January 2015. {{subscription required}}</ref> A brother, Thomas, born around 1862, died in South Africa in 1888.<ref>"Deaths", ''The Times'', 16 July 1888, p. 1.</ref>
Brodrick was the first woman to study Egyptology under [[Gaston Maspero]] at the [[Sorbonne]], and Hebrew and Semitic archaeology under [[Ernest Renan]] at the [[Collège de France]]. Neither had been encouraging at first. Maspero had objected, "But we do not take little girls here", and Renan had vowed "I have never taught a woman in my life, and I never will".<ref name=Jan>Janssen, Rosaling & Jac. (1999) "Excavating in the Petrie Museum" in A. Leahy & J. Tait (Eds.) ''Studies on Ancient Egypt in Honour of H.S. Smith''. London: [[Egypt Exploration Society]], pp. 151–156. {{ISBN|0856981516}}</ref> When Brodrick insisted on attending, Maspero took the matter up with the Sorbonne council who found nothing in the rules to prevent a woman attending. According to Brodrick, Maspero warned her that she would "probably have a very bad time" and indeed when she first attended she found the students to be rough, rude, and smelly. On one occasion they poured ink down her back. Brodrick simply laughed their tricks off and eventually became great friends with them.<ref name=Jan/>
==Career== Back in England, Brodrick entered [[College Hall, London]] in 1888 where she studied at [[University College London]] under [[Reginald Stuart Poole|Stuart Poole]] (co-founder with Amelia Edwards of the [[Egypt Exploration Society]]) and [[Peter le Page Renouf]]. She did not enter for a [[University of London]] degree due to her prior studies.<ref name=Times220733>"Dr. Mary Brodrick." by "A correspondent", ''The Times'', 22 July 1933, p. 14.</ref> She was a member of the Committee of Philology and Literary Archaeology of the [[World's Columbian Exposition]] in Chicago 1893 and did work in America for the Egyptian Exploration Fund. She was awarded the degree of Doctor of Philosophy in 1893 by the [[College of the Sisters of Bethany]], University of Kansas, the same institution that had also awarded a PhD to [[Amelia Edwards]].<ref name=Times220733 /><ref>"University Jottings", ''[[The Academy (periodical)|The Academy]]'', No. 1110, 12 August 1893, p. 131.</ref> She lectured at the [[British Museum]] and studied Egyptology under [[Flinders Petrie]] in 1893–94 and 1894–95.<ref name=Jan/> She held the Pfeiffer Fellowship of College Hall from 1894–96. In 1896, she was elected a life member of the [[Bibliothèque nationale]], Paris, and a life member of College Hall, London.<ref name=Times220733 />
From the mid 1890s, Brodrick spent most of her time outside England. She travelled to Italy, Greece and Egypt. She worked under Maspero<ref name=Times220733 /> in Egypt from 1897 to 1908<ref name=Jan/> and was one of the first female excavators in that country.<ref name="Willems">{{cite book|author=Willems, Harco|title=The Coffin of Heqata: (Cairo JdE 36418) : a Case Study of Egyptian Funerary Culture of the Early Middle Kingdom|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2fMiG2dGPpYC&pg=PA15|year=1996|publisher=Peeters|location=Leuven|isbn=978-90-6831-769-5|page=15}}</ref> In Egypt she had her head shaved for reason of hygiene.<ref>"London Notes and Comment", ''[[The Yorkshire Post]]'', 16 November 1934, p. 10.</ref> Brodrick became part of the British establishment in Egypt and knew [[Evelyn Baring, 1st Earl of Cromer|Lord Cromer]] and [[Herbert Kitchener, 1st Earl Kitchener|Kitchener]]. She took a signed portrait of Queen Victoria to a Bedouin sheikh who had been of assistance to the British. In 1913-14, she "took the salute" at Khartoum during the [[General Gordon|Gordon Memorial Service]].<ref name=Jan/>
In 1913, Brodrick was appointed a Lady of Grace of the [[Venerable Order of Saint John|Most Venerable Order of the Hospital of Saint John of Jerusalem]].<ref>"Order Of St. John Of Jerusalem", ''[[The Times]]'', 5 March 1913, p. 11.</ref> She was elected a member (later fellow) of the [[Royal Geographical Society]] in 1916.<ref>"Meetings: Royal Geographical Society: Session 1916-1917", ''The Geographical Journal'', Vol. 49, No. 2 (February 1917), p. 156.</ref> The Mary Brodrick Prize for Geography was given by [[University College London|University College]], London.<ref name=Jan/>
== Writing == Brodrick edited a new edition of [[Heinrich Karl Brugsch|Heinrich Brugsch-Bey]]'s ''Egypt under the Pharaohs'' in 1891, and in 1892 translated and edited [[Auguste Mariette]]'s ''Aperçu de l'histoire ancienne d'Egypte'' which was published by Scribner's in New York, 1892, as ''Outlines of Ancient Egyptian History''.
She took on the editorship of the 9th and 10th editions of [[Murray's Handbooks for Travellers|Murray's]] travel handbooks for Egypt (1896 and 1900)<ref>[http://grandhotelsegypt.com/?p=290 "Never hurry a Murray".] ''Egypt in the Golden Age of Travel'', 17 March 2012. Retrieved 28 December 2014.</ref> and also edited Murray's Syria and Palestine volume.
A selection of her papers and lectures on Egypt, edited by Eversley Robinson, were published posthumously in 1937.
== Death == Brodrick died on 13 July 1933 in [[Hindhead]], Surrey.<ref name=Times1933>"Deaths", ''The Times'', 15 July 1933, p. 1.</ref> Her funeral was at St. Alban's Church in that town. As far as is known, Brodrick never married and left no descendants. Years in Egypt had taken their toll and she was not in robust health in her later years. In the year of her death she gave two addresses to College Hall, titled "Retrospect and Prospect" and "Farewell and All Hail".<ref name=Jan/>
Brodrick left a net estate of £46168. She gave £500 to her friend [[Thyra Alleyne]], principal of College Hall, and the same amount to Lucie Dobson, bursar of the hall. She left £500 each to Cornelia Cracknell and Florence Collins of The School of Gardening, Clapham, Worthing. On her brother's Cecil's death, she left the portrait of her by N. Fulcher to College Hall. After some minor legacies of chattels and possessions, the residue of her estate was left two-thirds on trust to her brother and one-third to Mrs (later Dame) Eversley Chaning Robinson and then on to College Hall.<ref>"Bequest to Bootham School", ''The Yorkshire Post'', 24 August 1933, p. 5.</ref><ref>"Woman Author Leaves £46,000", ''The Daily Express'', 24 August 1933, p. 14.</ref> It was that, not inconsiderable, residue that provided the funds necessary to allow the completion of the long-planned extension to College Hall in 1934 which was named The Mary Brodrick Wing in her honour.<ref>"Extension Of College Hall", ''The Times'', 16 November 1934, p. 11.</ref> Her personal collection of antiquities have found their way to the [[Petrie Museum]] and her academic books to the Edwards Library.<ref name=Jan/>
